How much do moose eat?

Most of our studies on moose browsing come from wildlife ecology studies

(Renecker and Hudson 1985) tracked two free-range moose cows to study their voluntary intake over two years. The authors use two methods for estimating dry matter consumption: the ratio technique (fecal excretion vs the indigestibility of the diet) and the bite-count approach (measuring bite rate, simulated bite size and total foraging time). Summer consumption was 129 grams per kg of body weightˆ0.75 (per month I think), mid-winter dropped to 38 grams / kg BMˆ0.75 (again, per month?).

Table of moose intake results

- penned Alaska moose (Schwartz et al. 1981)

- penned and wild younger moose on Isle Royale (Miquelle 1979)

(Renecker and Hudson 1985) - Summer consumption was 129 grams per kg of body weightˆ0.75 (per month I think), mid-winter dropped to 38 grams / kg BMˆ0.75 (again, per month?).

Renecker, Lyle A., and Robert J. Hudson. 1985. “Estimation of Dry Matter Intake of Free-Ranging Moose.” The Journal of Wildlife Management 49 (3): 785–92. https://doi.org/10.2307/3801712.

- average daily consumption in mid-july = 9,938 (SD 836) grams

- net energy requirement for maintaining free-range [[moose]] cows = 399 KJ / kg of BMˆ

(McArt et al. 2009)

McArt, Scott H., Donald E. Spalinger, William B. Collins, Erik R. Schoen, Timothy Stevenson, and Michele Bucho. 2009. “Summer Dietary Nitrogen Availability as a Potential Bottom-up Constraint on Moose in South-Central Alaska.” Ecology 90 (5): 1400–1411. https://doi.org/10.1890/08-1435.1.

## Takeaways

- summer dietary nitrogen availability is a nutrient constraint on moose

- Denali cows were simulated to gain 4-6% of body mass across the summer

- moose reach peak body mass in fall (Mautz 1978, Adamczewski et al. 1987, Schwartz et al. 1987)

- reproductive success linked to august body mass (Cameron et al. 1993, Schwartz and Hundertmark 1993, Cameron and Ver Hoef 1994, Barrett 1982)
